Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery ovoid neck-amphora; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of Achilles (upper body with added red on neck, breast and flank remaining, holding helmet by nose-piece in right hand) to right; facing him, Thetis (left hand in faded added white, draped breast and upper arm remaining, holding a shield with faded white roundels on rim and possible sword; at left, male hand to right holding spear as staff.
Producer name: Attributed to: The Painter of London B76
Curator's comments: Beazley and Payne suggest that Thetis also holds a sword. For parallels, See LIMC I, Achilles nos. 188 and 200; London British Museum 1922,0615.1; Munich 1450 in ABV, 86, no. 10.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B600.29)
Beazley & Payne 1929 / Attic Black Figured Fragments from Naukratis (p. 261, no. 28)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 220, no. B62)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 232, no. 1)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0019) (Phase 1)
Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XIII, no. 5)
